text:

A heroic nightclub bouncer run over by an ex-soldier who had been attacking drinkers with an 18-inch SAW has spoken for the first time about the horrific ordeal. 
Dramatic CCTV footage shows how the drama unfolded in a Cardiff suburb - as the boozed-up builder swings the tool threatening to "slash" and "stab" people meant to be enjoying a fun night out. 
Howard Young was doing paperwork in the back of Miss Jones bar in Whitchurch when he got a call telling him there was an attacker at the front of the building. 
The 48-year-old told how he was expecting to find a man with a sword - but when he arrived outside he was confronted with builder Mark Burgess slashing wildly at revellers with the tool. 
The drunk brickie had pulled the 18-inch saw from his van - which he later used to make his escape. 
Howard told WalesOnline : “We ran to the front door and brought the customers inside to get them out of the way. 
“Then myself and my colleagues went out looking for this guy attacking people in the street.” Mark Burgess walked armed with the saw in the middle of the street (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
Howard and colleagues Oktay Alan and Gerald Dunn then saw Burgess storming towards them. 
“It was frightening,” Howard explained. 
He could see then Burgess was armed with a saw - not a sword. Bouncer Howard Young ensured his customers were safe before racing to confront the attacker (Photo: Peter Bolter) 
“He attacked a couple of people and then he went to his vehicle,” Howard said. 
They then tried to stop the thug driving off. 
“My colleague opened the door of the van and I said ‘Get the keys, get the keys.’ 
“But he put his foot down and swerved out to the right." 
Howard was at the side of the van. Burgess swings the saw at one man in the melee (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
“The driver’s door was open so it hit me,” he said. 
“I stayed on my feet but I travelled backward. It happened so quickly, it was a split second. 
“My concern was trying to stop him leaving and getting him out of the vehicle. 
“It could have been much worse.” Burgess was handed a 16-month prison sentence, suspended for 18 months (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
Burgess went on the rampage in Merthyr Road, Cardiff, last November 6 after spending the day of the Wales vs Australia autumn international drinking in the city centre. 
The 35-year-old, from Washford Avenue, Llanrumney, then drove to Miss Jones, where he parked on double yellow lines. 
He couldn’t get in because it was closing – so he threatened to “slash” and “stab” people. Burgess was swinging wildly with the 18-inch saw (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
One man suffered a wound to his arm that needed four stitches. His girlfriend was left with cut hands after trying to stop the assault. 
“All we could think of was to protect who we could and get the saw off him,” Howard said. 
A CCTV camera captured the incident that showed Burgess brandishing the weapon. Customers fled as Burgess came close to the bar (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
He denied dangerous driving after being arrested. 
A breath test showed he had 61 micrograms of alcohol in 100 millilitres of breath – the limit is 35. Read More 
“I’ll probably see him again because he lives in the same area as me,” Howard, from Rumney, Cardiff, said. 
“I don’t know what I would say to him.” 
He felt Burgess had “got away with it” because he was spared jail. The attack happened outside the Miss Jones Bar and Grill in Whitchurch, Cardiff (Photo: South Wales Echo) 
Cardiff Crown Court heard Burgess had previous convictions for drink-driving, drunk and disorderly behaviour, and assault occasioning actual bodily harm. 
He was given a 16-month prison sentence, suspended for 18 months, after admitting drink-driving and making threats with an offensive weapon. Read More 
Burgess initially hit the headlines in December after spending £350 making a wooden shelter with a fire alarm, light, insulation and a lock for a couple living on the streets. Burgess was over the drink drive limit (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE)
